title: 114_hr5270
content:
The "Efficient Marine Mammal Protection Act" abolishes the Marine Mammal Commission and transfers its functions to the Director of the United States Fish and Wildlife Service. Conforming and clerical amendments are also made. The Marine Mammal Protection Act of 1972 is amended to transfer functions from the Marine Mammal Commission to the Director of the United States Fish and Wildlife Service. The Marine Mammal Protection Act of 1972 is amended to transfer functions from the Marine Mammal Commission to the Director of the United States Fish and Wildlife Service, including changing references from "Chairman" to "Director" and updating headings to reflect the new authority. The Marine Mammal Protection Act of 1972 is amended to transfer functions to the Director of the United States Fish and Wildlife Service, updating references and headings accordingly. The Marine Mammal Protection Act of 1972 is amended to transfer functions to the Director of the United States Fish and Wildlife Service, updating references and headings accordingly. Changes include renumbering sections and specifying the duties of the United States Fish and Wildlife Service. The Marine Mammal Protection Act of 1972 is amended to transfer functions to the Director of the United States Fish and Wildlife Service, updating references and headings accordingly. This includes amending various acts to replace "Marine Mammal Commission" with "Director of the United States Fish and Wildlife Service." SEC. 4. REFERENCES.

Any reference in Federal law, Executive order, rule, regulation, or document pertaining to the Marine Mammal Commission now refers to the Director of the United States Fish and Wildlife Service.

SEC. 5. EXERCISE OF AUTHORITIES.

The Director of the United States Fish and Wildlife Service can exercise all authorities previously held by the Marine Mammal Commission for transferred functions.

SEC. 6. SAVINGS PROVISIONS. All legal documents issued by the President, Marine Mammal Commission, or other government officials in relation to transferred functions will remain in effect until modified or revoked by authorized officials or by law. This Act will not affect any pending proceedings or applications before the Marine Mammal Commission. Orders issued in these proceedings will continue until modified or revoked by authorized officials or by law. The Act will not impact ongoing suits or actions involving the Marine Mammal Commission or its officers, ensuring continuity in legal proceedings despite any transfer of functions. The Act ensures that ongoing suits involving the Marine Mammal Commission will continue with the new officer or office if functions are transferred. Statutory requirements for notice, hearings, and review will apply to the new agency head and officers. SEC. 7 of the Act allows for the transfer of assets, including property, records, and funds, to officials or agencies as directed by the Director of the Office of Management and Budget for use in connection with the transferred functions. SEC. 8 addresses delegation and assignment within the new agency. SEC. 8 of the Act allows for delegation and assignment of functions transferred to officials, who can further delegate to designated officers and employees as necessary. The official remains responsible for the administration of the function. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will determine functions transferred under the Act and make necessary incidental transfers of personnel, assets, and funds to carry out the provisions of the Act. This includes terminating affairs of entities affected by the Act. The Act may require further measures and dispositions to achieve its purposes. SEC. 10. AVAILABILITY OF EXISTING FUNDS: Appropriations and funds for terminated functions remain available for necessary expenses. 

SEC. 11. DEFINITIONS: "Function" includes duties, powers, and programs. "Office" includes various organizational entities.
